												'Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball' is a nice little physics puzzle game. I recommend it if you like the genre. It won't entertain you for many hours but you can hardly expect that for this price. When the game's on sale it only costs a quarter, so you can count on at least getting your money's worth of fun, and maybe even a bit more than that. The mechanicsThe game is about getting a ball to a target but you don't control the ball directly. Instead, you turn the screen by moving your mouse left and right, which causes the ball to move. This ball, however, is fragile and breaks easily. So you'll have to avoid things like dropping the ball from great heights, dropping it on top of spikes or even touching spikes, leaving it underneath logs that come pounding down, and so on. In some levels, you can rotate the screen completely (360°) but in certain levels you can only rotate the screen e.g. 90°. This angle is clearly shown in the top right corner of the screen.Progressing in the gameWhen you finish a level, more than one of the next levels opens up. Say you just finished level 7. Coming back to the level selection screen, you may see levels 8, 9 and 10 opening up. What this means is that if you're stuck on one of the levels, the game doesn't have to end there for you but you can try one of the other levels and advance through that one instead. And you will find easier levels further on, even in the highest level numbers of this game. That's a bit strange but it doesn't have to be a negative thing. It means you'll be able to explore and try out all the levels of the game, even if you decide to just tackle the easier ones. If you prefer challenging levels, you'll find those, too. All the way up to what I would call 'masochistic difficulty'. Unless I'm missing something, I count a total of 83 levels. Music and graphicsThe music was ok. It fits the game rather nicely. And it's varied enough so it doesn't get on your nerves. If you're easily annoyed with basic background tunes, you can turn down the volume of the music and/or sound effects through the game's menu, or even switch them off completely. The graphics are basic but polished enough for a puzzle game. Check the screenshots to give you an idea. You can adjust the resolution and toggle fullscreen, AA and V-Sync on or off.Steam extras'Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball' has 5 Steam Trading Cards. You'll get 3 for running the game.The game does not have Steam Achievements, which is too bad. A game like this could really use them. There are so many games -especially puzzle games- to be played these days, so most people will just finish the levels they can finish and then move on. Achievements would have added some extra motivation to finish more levels.

												Despite the thumbs-down, this is definitely a game a minority of people will enjoy (and I'm still trying to finish some of the final stages), but let me explain.If this title were cut down into about half, maybe two-thirds of the 100* stages, and they cherry-picked only the best, you would have an incredibly solid little puzzle game. The issue comes in that there are sets of levels I would refer to as "poorly designed".They're trial and error machines with no hints or ability to solve them short of flinging yourself to death on the course repeatedly. Examples would be multiple which start you at a high point, then give you a left or right direction to fall in. For one thing, the game's title is spot-on: your ball is fragile and tapping ANYTHING over a certain velocity will kill you**, so if you pick the wrong path: bam, dead. Alright, but then what happens when a level is nothing but left/right paths where you have to memorize which is correct and which isn't? Or a single left/right fall but one side has a cushion at the bottom to catch you (which you need to aim for precisely, those ain't big) and the other doesn't. And you have to blind-aim your momentum to land on something that's way off screen.I hope you're beginning to get my point here.But at the other end of the scale, there are stages which create some really fun challenges, where you have a full 360-degree playfield and you're working your momentum in platforming you don't see in anything else, managing momentum and angle of rotation and trying to find the exit before you can even maneuver down to it. When the game gives you the freedom in a stage to approach it however you like, it really takes off for a few minutes at a time.Also, I feel this needs to be stated: this game is ugly as sin, consisting of nothing but stock textures used over and over in eye-searing ways. I think there are under 10 textures in the entire game, and sometimes they will be backgrounds, sometimes foregrounds, and usually in clashing, jarring fashion.* I presume there are 100 levels. Where I'm currently at, around 15 tiles on a 100-tile board refuse to open up, whether I clear things adjacent to them or not.** Except in "Super Ball" stages. These are poorly designed for other reasons, because you're invincible to physics damage in them, but basically controlling rubber and a lot of them involve precision-landings above hazard fields and slowing your momentum. It's not fun at all.

												I'm always keen to try out a new marble madness-esque game. Fragile Ball is basic 2D 'marble' game of skill, with one simple goal of using gravity to get your ball to the exit, while avoiding the inevitable traps. Certainly sounds simple, but in practice its one hell of a challenge!Hard is perhaps an understatement. Level design plays a big role in this, with plenty of hazards to avoid, placed in just the right spots to have you pulling out your hair. Some level design reminded me of the old classic, Crazy Machines, where one small incorrect move and it all falls apart in milliseconds, followed by a swift restart while you mumble to yourself that you can do better. There are also other levels though that are more open/scrolling, but regardless of the level type the restarts will be many! It can be brutal .. I found myself swearing & groaning at my screen on more than one occasion. I do enjoy a challenge though; something that takes practice.With the high level of difficulty, I find this game is best suited to short sessions. 5-10mins over a coffee in the morning is good to wake the brain up. If I get stuck for too long, I stop to prevent the frustration building. Along with more 'standard' levels previously mentioned, there are also some maze levels to challenge you. These are generally bigger levels allowing a larger degree rotation. Standard levels generally limit the range of angle you can choose giving more of a fixed direction - but this does vary quite a bit. Graphics are rather bland, along with animations and menus, but they do the job.Although I do like the game overall, there are a few things that bugged me that I think could be improved upon. The mouse sensitivity has a limited range on the slider. With my Logitech mouse & slider all the way down, the movement still was too sensitive for my liking. This restricted the precision over the ball, but on reflection I can't be 100% sure if its just the mouse sensitivity or harsh physics in the game design.Also found the maze levels when run in full screen made me feel nauseous. The spinning speed (and almost constant spinning sometimes), particularly when view full screen gave me some motion sickness. In a smaller screen (you can play in windowed mode) it was ok for me. Something to warn people about if they are sensitive to such things. Most levels were ok, but a few were tough to deal with.Running in window mode was a bit problematic as well, as the mouse didn't lock to the game screen. I would move my mouse too far & it would flick back to windows, killing control over the ball. I wouldn't recommend this to everyone (some will just find it infuriating!). It's not the best example I have seen in the genre with some flaws, but you are a gamer with patience & persistence, who likes a hardcore challenge then this is a good value puzzler to add to your collection.Disclosure: Copy of this game was provide for review purposes.If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

-Quick Review-Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball is a physics game developed by Bimboosoft Co.,Ltd. and released 2015.Okay real talk, do you remember those old wooden maze games with the number holes, and the little steel ball you would navigate through the maze by tilting the maze up down, left or right? After a sequence of google searches I've come up with the title "Labyrinth marble game".Take that concept, and make a game out of it. BAM, that's Marble Mayhem Fragile Ball, and depending on your opinion of that retro physical game, that will effect your opinion on this game. Full disclaimer: I'm terrible at the real life version. Do read on!


Kids these days, what would you be without your graphics, your hocky, your playstations, and the donkey kongs? 
A Screenshot of Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Gameplay: Easiest controls I can describe: Mouse to tilt right and left. BAM! Review done, roll the credits.Okay, I can elaborate more on it. Some people seem to have problems with mouse sensitivity, I did notice you can tilt slightly with the keyboard but I pity you if you need to rely on the right and left arrows; I didn't try any levels with them. Some levels let you tilt the camera more then others.The idea is your moving a ball around a maze, and if your ball hits the ground or spikes it will break and you'll need to restart from the beginning. There are actually two kinds of balls, a blue bouncy ball which won't break from fall damage (but instead you need to worry about spikes, and using bounce physics to your advantage), and the regular brown ball which will break if it builds up too much momentum before running into the wall.


Broken... Just like my dreams for beating this game (jk, no dreams. I don't have the patience to do the harder levels)

There are actually two difficulties for the game, I mainly played Normal because, while I am stupid and do like a good challenge, I'm not a sadist! I played maybe 4 levels on hard difficulty and discovered very quickly I didn't want to play that difficulty (the ball is just significantly less forgiving.Conclusion:  How much entertainment is in this game? I played a few hours legitimately amused an entertained. It would be interesting to see if controllers or motion controls worked with this game (unfortunately I don't have access to either, so I can't tell you if they work).For the asking price, meh. This game is alright... If you're looking for a quick play, or something to distract your kids with, or want some steam trading cards, go ahead and pick this game up.

												Didn't realize I purchased this game in a puzzle-games bundle, but I still played it to try it out. I was a bit excited to play this when I realized what this game is, because this game reminded me of the wooden boxs where you have to carefully navigate a metalic ball through a maze/obstacles to reach the end. However, when I booted  the game up, I was immediately turned-off by the game's graphics. It was absolutely horrible to the eyes and I had to blink multiple times to read the font on the menu page as the background contstantly changed with different scenes in the game. After getting past configurations and starting the game, the first few levels interested me and kept me going. Allthough, I did notice that the rotation sensitivity does change a bit per level and this is most likely due to the rotation constraint built into the game, which would devalue the game some more as you might end up spending more time calibrating the mouse sensitivity more than attempting the level. (I still dislike the poor graphics used as a background. Please have more ascetically pleasing backgrounds in the future to boost its value :/)In regards to the game design, the design is simple and easy to grasp, but a major deviation is that your degree of rotation is limited. This changes how the game is/can be played and doesn't make it much fun for me. Likewise, having the idea of the ball being fragile makes you want to navigate the game carefully, but then you introduce the super (nearly indestructuble as you cam bounce it hard against a wall, but pops on spikes) ball, which changes the game entirely. Yes, the super ball works to introduce variation, but I think it'll do even better if you have themed levels separated from each other where one theme is fragile ball puzzles and the other is the super ball. About the game's physics, I'm not sure how well-tuned they are. During a maze level where I could actually do 360 rotations, I had the ball rolling very fast and I made the mistake of turning the wrong way. which had the ball free-falling down a pretty long way down. I naturally thought I had to restart the process, because it'll smash. However, it did NOT. I was thoroughly surprised and thought I was lucky. However, when I did the same process again, it smashed as expected. So either the physics isn't consistent or that was a bug that I proc'ed by chance. Overall, I did find some amusement in this game as it brought back memories. However, I didn't exactly enjoy the game that much due to the graphics and mechanics. I say 3/10.
